content.description: Climb the dark chimney and crack located to the right of Fool's Ruby. Finish the route by either climbing to the left with 3 bolts and a hard 8+ move or finish right by climbing the crumbly 5.6 face with no protection.  Perhaps a choice made easier with a shot of Talisker single malt from the Isle of Skye.

climbs.name: Shattered
climbs.fa: (TR) Kelby Burnham, Resa Ashbachar, FL: Bob Gaines and Tony Grice, 2008

content.description: Begin just left of the Fetus and make a step-across move/dyno to gain a ledge with the hands. (This maneuver will be more difficult the shorter you are) Hand traverse left, then power over a bulge (10c, height dependent) on knobs. The middle section has some enjoyable steep face climbing, with a 10c slab move above the fourth bolt.

climbs.name: Picnic
climbs.fa: Norm Sauce and Bob Dominick, February 1970

content.description: Just left of the picnic table up against the right side of the S Face of this crag, there is a well-defined crack & runnel system that runs up and left of a dark vertical section of the wall, then up the left side/corner of the buttress at the right edge of the wall. Climb that to the top. OK warm up on a freezing morning, but not good for much else.

Make easy moves to the first bolt (drilled angle) about 20 feet up and then wander up the narrow, low-angled rib above passing three more bolts. It's a little ways from the last bolt to the anchor but the angle kicks back and it gets easier.

A direct start (5.9) can be done up the front of the rib and can even be lead by pre-clipping the first bolt.
content.protection:
4 bolts, 2 bolt ring anchor

Two bolt anchor for the belay but it's best to rap off the anchors just to the left on

McStain

.
content.location:
On the narrow rib between

Picnic

and

Feast

.

content.description: To the right of Talisker's Choice climb a series of cracks to the top and continue up the crumbly face of Fool's Ruby 5.6 R or harder cracks to the right.

climbs.name: McStain
climbs.fa: Marilyn Goninatti, Todd Gordon, Brett Pinar, Tim Pinar

content.description: Follow the gold streak up the gritty slab with the crux moving past the first bolt. Once past the last bolt it's a little runout but the angle kicks back and it gets much easier.
content.protection:
3 bolts, 2 bolt ring anchor (all 3/8").

Optional 1.25 inch piece in the horizontal between bolts two and three.
content.location:
The obvious gold streak left of

Picnic

.

content.description:
Fun moves at the crux on lesser quality rock, but the top half of this route climbs an enjoyable slab on excellent stone.

Start just right of a small bush at opposing side pulls and lieback into the pocketed crack above which higher becomes a flake ending at a horizontal crack; continue above up a nice slab to finish parallel with

McStain

.
content.location:
Located 10 feet left of

McStain

at a right-slanting crack/seam.

content.description:
Start up Picnic for 6 feet and then move left to climb the narrow face between it and

McStain

by way of the numerous and unique solution pockets; finishes past a pair of black intrusions near the top.
content.location: This is the face between McStain and Picnic but totally independent of either route.

content.description:
This is a so-so route. It's general direction is clear, but specifics not in a few places, with some variation in difficulty and quality depending upon the precise line taken. In all cases, at least minor runouts will be experienced. In my case, the climbing also seemed a tad hard for 5.6. Maybe 5.7 or 5.8.This is one of the longer routes on Campfire. It can be done in a  pitch or in two, depending on how much pro & how many slings you use- determining in how much drag you end up with.

Start more or less in the center of the S face, in a well defined crack system. Climb up a few moves to get established and get in some pro, climbing up for a bit before committing to a junky crack or a good face left of it (without a crack) Vogel's book implies a defined line, and while this is marked as a crack, it appears to go left top the face _variation, which was seeming nicer, though unprotected (5.5?  S/VS).  We chose that over the less interesting crack.  After and additional 70' of climbing, you pop up onto a ledge and see a finishing crack, up into this and over the top on larger cams (3" or so?) gets you to the top of the crag.

Descending is either an exposed and insecure scramble down a long sloping ramp to the East, or a long walk back around from the N or W side. Worth the effort to climb it? YES. Worth the effort required to get back down? MAYBE.
content.protection: A standard rack, with some considerable runouts.

content.description: Crux is a short almost-vertical section at the start. Then trend far left to the top. Crosses "Fool's Ruby" from right to left.
content.protection: Five bolts total. Two knob tie-offs and 1/2 to 3/4 inch piece on the traverse.
content.location: This is on the far right end of the crag.

climbs.name: Kundalini-Linguini-Weenie
climbs.fa: Tom Atherton, Cyndie Bransford & Todd Gordon, 1989

content.description: This route is toward the middle of the south face of Campfire Crag and is approached in any number of easy cracks to its base. You'll have a few moves to get to the first bolt so take along some medium cams. It's sandbagged moving from the second bolt to the top. Be that as it may, it's a fine route. There are rap anchors.

climbs.name: Impatience  (aka  A Diamond, A Pony, and a Ferrari )

content.description: This is the plated face on the far left side of the south face of Campfire Crag, to the right of the Heart Slab. No fixed gear, 2 bolt rap station at ledge with the small cat's claw bush. This climb starts with stemming/chimney moves to reach the plates. It is also located just left of the bolted climb Shattered.
content.protection: A small mixed rack of trad gear (small to large).
content.location: Left side of the So. face of Campfire Crag.

content.description:
Steep friction moves up the face lead to a scooped out area and a high bolt below an obvious black intrusion. Move left after clipping the bolt, find the hidden edge and then make a long reach to the black intrusion and power over the bulge.

Higher, progressively easier moves up and left lead into the 2nd bolt of the regular route, which is followed to the top.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 1 FP, a couple pieces 1-2.5", slings for tieoffs and a 2 bolt anchor/rap.
content.location:
Between

Banquet

and

Lunch

and 10' right of the normal start.

climbs.name: I Love my Marine
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Brett Pinar, Tim Pinar, Resa Ashbachar, Kat Green, Aaron

content.description:
Start up featured rock passing two bolts and a good knob tie-off to reach a slanting crack (.75 - 1" piece) before heading up and right to a fixed lost arrow piton at the base of the upper slab. Clip the pin and then pass a straight-in crack (1.5 - 2.5" piece) to reach a final bolt just before the anchors.

Fun climbing with a good variety of moves throughout it's length make this a worthwhile route if in the area.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 1 FP, optional slings for tieoffs and a 2 bolt anchor/rap

content.description: Scramble up the gully left of and behind campsite 42.  Towards the top, on the main south face of Campfire Crag, this route angles up and left past two bolts to the right end of a horizontal, then up past three bolts from there. Gear belay and walk/scramle off.
content.protection: Five bolts (all 3/8"), gear to 2.5" for an anchor.

content.description: An awkward hand crack leads to easier going and the top of the flake.  Steep, exposed, poorly protected face climbing takes you to the top.
content.location: This route is on the far right end of the south face.  A right-slanting flake goes half way up.

content.description: Begin just left of Banquet. You may need to stick clip the first bolt if you're under 6 ft. The initial section is the crux, and very height dependent. If you're under about 6 feet tall it may shut you down. After that, fun moves on steep flakes lead to the top.
Direct start to Feminine Itch. Crux is right away, but well protected by the bolt.

climbs.name: Feminine Itch
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Matt Hines , Andrea Tomaszweski, Karen Miller

content.description:
This climb starts in the back of site 41, about 18' from the picnic table to the right. Start behind a creosote in a trough/groove with a hole down low and a bolt. Climb this to a ledge, then move left and climb the face above past three bolts to a two bolt anchor/rap.

A direct variation (5.10b/c) starts about 15' to the left. Climb past a horizontal and a bolt to the ledge and join the regular route.

Climb up and establish feet to clip a bolt, then climb the crux (insecure, & possibly height-dependant) to palm smear up above. Then climb easier rock (ground fall potential, but 5.5 or so) up to distinct dark features at a slight bulge and 2 more bolts. Top out and belay on a 2-bolt anchor.

Fun, puzzling, and Oh my god I can't believe I stuck to that!?!? I describe the grips as "palming an oversized basketball."
content.protection:
4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor/rap

The first bolt is 6 meters up, the second 20 meters, but the climbing between is not hard.
content.location:
Just right of

Sokolove

which climbs up a low angled rib.

content.description:
This adventure starts high above the desert and features well-protected slab climbing that wanders upwards past many bolts, not all of which are in the best locations.

Although orginally done as two seperate routes, Leftovers (5.9) and Cold Carnitas (5.10b), with a belay in a slanting crack midway, it makes more sense to combine them into a single pitch.
content.location:
Located up and left from the prominent crack of

Lunch

which can be used to approach the route.

Another option is to climb

I Love my Marine

to below it's final headwall and cut left to join the route.

content.description: This is a left leaning crack in the middle of the south face of Campfire Crag behind CS 41. Setting pro is a breeze; and the route, all in all, is much fun.
